title: Willian Massami Watanabe - Curriculum
description: As a Computer Science professor, stands as a passionate Web developer, lecturing development practices associated to Web technologies and Web engineering practices (such as: eXtreme Programming, TDD - Test-Driven Design, Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery). Eager to contribute by developing quality assured Web applications, also considering attributes such as usability, maintanability and multi-platform characteristic of the Web. Current research projects involve the use of machine learning to enhance the state-of-art of Web engineering practices.
keywords: Willian Massami Watanabe, curriculum, Web Developer, Front-end Web Engineer, Ajax, Web 2.0, Web usability, Web accessibility, HTML5, Test-Driven Development, Continuous Integration, Continuous Delivery, React.js, REDUX
author: Willian Massami Watanabe

sections.title: introduction
sections.headline: Front-end Web Engineer
sections.paragraph: Passionate Software Engineer specialized in Frontend development, JavaScript and Accessibility, with experience in Fullstack development and Web engineering practices, such as: eXtreme Programming, TDD - Test-Driven Design, Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery. Current research projects involve the use of machine learning to enhance Web engineering practices, automatically detecting Cross-Browser and Cross-Platform Incompatibilities and Accessibility requirements in web applications.

list.description: Front-end developer experienced in the use of cutting edge technologies, with the objective of allowing rich interactions for users in the Web, exercising Web 2.0 and HTML5 core concepts.
Specialist in Web Engineering practices such as Continuous Integration, Continuous Delivery and Test-Driven Design; for assuring the quality of large scale web projects.
Advanced knowledge in the area of computer interfaces design, with experience in the field of Web accessibility and usability issues.
Web standards (HTML, CSS, JS and others)
Web services, RESTFul and RPC (Remote Procedure Calls)
High Performance and Scalability in the Web Platform
Test-Driven Development, Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery
Cloud Computing concepts and Microservices
Web accessibility (WCAG 2.0 and WAI-ARIA)
JavaScript / Node.js
Ajax Design patterns
React.js / REDUX
PHP
Python
Design patterns
Machine learning (R or SKLEARN)
Docker

Professor at UTFPR. Brazil 2012.: Computer Science professor with emphasis in Web Development, Software Engineering and Human-Computer Interaction. Lecture topics include: Web standards, JavaScript fullstack (with React.js and Express.js) and Web engineering practices (TDD, CI and CD). Main research topics include: Web Accessibillity, ARIA automatic evaluation strategies, XBI - Cross Browser Inconsistencies automatic detection, Web Applications Testing and use of Machine learning for improving the Web engineering process.

Ocasional Open-Source contributor for Reactstrap and React-bootstrap. 2020: React.js and Bootstrap based interface components libraries. Contributions made to this project are associated to solving general issues raised for the projects, as well as ARIA based implementations. The projects also makes use of Popper.js and Enzyme for testing.

Software enginner at Yahoo!. Brazil 2011-2012.: working specifically on two applications: Meme and Profile. Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment strategies demand constant effort, while keeping the quality of continous delivery of features in the Web. Exercising Test-Driven Design, eXtreme Programming, Scrumm practices and dealing with performance and scalability non-functional requirements in Web systems. Also, contributed to other projects associated to Cloud Service Engineering, Operations Engineering and Mobile Web applications development.

Ph.D. CAPES Scholarship at São Paulo University - ICMC (Mathematics and Computer Science Institute). Brazil, 2010.: part of the of the Ph.D. program of ICMC-USP, with the project entitled "Automatic Accessibility Evaluation in RIA - Rich Internet Applications". This research was financed by CAPES and works in the area of Web Accessibility, Web Usability, Web Engineering, MDD, RIA - Rich Internet Applications and Ajax. The Ph.D. project was conducted under the orientation of Prof. Dra. Renata Pontin de Mattos Fortes.

Master of Science FAPESP Scholarship at São Paulo University - ICMC (Mathematics and Computer Science Institute). Brazil, 2008-2010: inserted at project PorSimples which was financed by FAPESP and Microsoft Research, was responsible by the integration of text processing operations and interface design of the Facilita. The Facilita is a web application that works as an assistive technology facilitating portuguese reading activities on web pages through the use of automatic text summarization and simplification techniques. Simple interactions, usability and accessibility issues are essential requirements to the Facilita implementation and are the main themes of the research. JavaScript and AJAX characteristics provide some of the key features of design's simplicity and usability in Facilita. The project was developed under orientation of Prof. Dra. Renata Pontin de Mattos Fortes.

Qualipso Scholarship at São Paulo University - ICMC (Mathematics and Computer Science Institute). Brazil, 2010-2010: the Qualipso - Quality Platform for Open Source Software project aims at elaboration a software maturity framework for Open Source Software (OMM - OpenSource Maturity Model). The Qualipso project has the objective of elaborating technologies, processes and policies that facilitate the development of Open Source quality assured software. The activities realized in the project involved the integration of different applications with the use of webservices technologies (RESTFul).

IT Analyst at Guenka Software Development. Brazil, 2007-2008: Part of the team responsible by the remote marketing software implementation, through the use of mobile devices, an optimized communication protocol (due to limitations of the mobile platform) and databases server applications. Collaborated in the development of a server applications that allowed other applications remote update through the use of XML-RPC.

ITI (Information Technology Initiation) CNPq Scholarship at Guenka Software Development. Brazil, 2006-2007: collaborated in the development of a communication channel between mobile devices and web servers. The communication was made between Java Servlet containners and mobile devices (Handhelds) with the use of XML-RPC to exchange server persistent data.

Jetpack for Learning Design Challenge Leader: managed a team participation on the Jetpack for Learning Design Challenge of Mozilla. In this design challenge, our team proposed the development of Educational Facilita making use of teh Jetpack extensions framework for Firefox. We implemented a reading assistance browser extension using multiple Ajax technologies and other resources available in the Jetpack platform.

Google Student Award: success application in the Google Student Award for the 7th International Cross-Disciplinary Conference on Web Accessibility (W4A 2010), in Raleigh USA co-located with the Ninteenth International World Wide Web Conference. The award granted financial support for the student to attend the W4A 2010 Conference.
Ph.D. in Computer Science, São Paulo University (ICMC-USP). São Carlos - SP, Brazil, 2014.
Master of Science in Computer Science, São Paulo University (ICMC-USP). São Carlos - SP, Brazil. 2010.
Bachelor of Science in Computer Science, Londrina State University (UEL). Londrina - PR, Brazil, 2008.
First Certificate in English, University of Cambridge, 2002.
Network and Computer building and maintenance, Technology Education Center, IAPEC, Brazil, 2004.
Machine learning online non-credit course authorized by Stanford University and offered through Coursera, 2016.

React Native based mobile app: React Native app for taking and storing pictures. It was implemented as a proof-of-concept for learning React native development platform. The app was organized using Material Bottom tabs components and Redux (using the Thunk middleware for executing async actions). Furthermore, its tests were implemented using Jest, react-test-renderer and Continuous integration practices.

React.js/Redux based homepage: implementation of this webpage using React.js and Redux (using the Thunk middleware for executing Ajax). The applications was created using CRA script with the Redux template. Furthermore, its tests were implemented using Jest and Continuous integration practices.

Cross-browser feature extractor: a Selenium based implementation developed for extracting data from web applications as rendered in different browsers and mobile devices. The collector was implemented with the goal of collecting attributes from DOM elements as rendered in different browsers. Then, using this data for comparing how web applications are rendered in different browsers, composing a dataset for identifying Cross-browser incompatibilities. The project was implemented using APPIUM and the data is supposed to feed classification algorithms for detecting cross-browser incompatibilities.

ARIA landmarks detection scripts: web crawler feature extractor, classification scripts and image reporter for ARIA landmarks, for enhancing the accessibility of web applications. These scripts extract DOM-elements features, train classification models and apply these models to identify ARIA landmarks on web applications.

XBI classification scripts: machine learning based scripts used for classification of Cross-browser incompatibilities (using Support Vector Machines, Decision Trees, Random Forest and Multi Layered Perceptron). These scripts use a variety of approaches for classification problems, namely using python, alongside data science APIs, such as: Scikit.

SLR Text classification scripts supervised learning scripts for conducting Document classification on systematic literature (using Natural language processing techniques, Embeddings and Multi Layer Perceptrons). These scripts use a variety of approaches for classification problems, namely using python, alongside data science APIs, such as: Scikit, Tensorflow and Keras.

React UI components: UI components implementation built on React.js. The project implements ARIA accessibility standards, tested with Jest and serves as an example of Continuous integration practices.

NYT searcher: example web application, which searches the New York Times JSON API for articles. The application was built with React.js, using REDUX to manage the state and SAGA to manage async calls to the API. This application was covered with tests implemented in Jest and running in Travis-CI.

watinha.com homepage: this is a presentation project, which makes use of different web technologies to improve the user experience in the curriculum. The source code is fully available in Github. This project makes use of Jasmine, as a JavaScript Behavior Driven Development framework; CasperJS, to simulate the browser environment during functional tests; JSHint, to validate the JavaScript source code against JS code standards; Mustache template engine, to generate the webpages from templates; CSS and JS code compression techniques to generate faster webpages with compressed JavaScript and CSS files; performance testing with yslow on the production environment of the application; Halstead, Cyclomatic Complexity and Code-coverage metrics, using grunt-complexity plugin for the complexity metrics and istanbul for the code coverage; and finally, the complete build process of the project is managed through Grunt task manager.

aria-check-menus: a Selenium WebDriver implementation which has the goal of automatically identifying Drop-down menu widgets in web applications. This project uses the Selenium WebDriver API, browser mutation observers and DOM attributes to navigate through web applications and identify menu widget implementations.

javacmd: boilerplate structure for Java projects. It includes a single Makefile which automatically compile Java source code, generates jar executable files, calculates dependencies based in a single jar directory, runs JUnit tests, generates JPA - Java Persistence API configuration files and generates JEE - Java Enterprise Edition applications structure. The goal of this project is to ease the development of Java projects with no use of IDEs. It is similar to Maven, however much simplier, with no XML configuration files.

tabindex-counter: a CasperJS script which collects HTML attributes metrics from webpages. This script was used to investigate how a large amount of websites implement Focus Navigation requirements and whether these implementations are associated to ARIA specific design recommendations.

aria-check: a Firefox Addon built on top of the Addon-SDK. The Addon runs a generic test-suite, which searches for Tab Widgets implementations and evaluates whether it implements ARIA specification requirements. The ARIA specification describes the use of semantic markup (such as: roles, aria-labels, among others) and keyboard interaction mechanisms for making JavaScript based interface components accessible.

Pyccuracy Accessibility Actions: The main objective of this project is to implement accessibility actions for the pyccuracy, web acceptance testing application. Pyccuracy makes use of natural language expressions to generate user stories and acceptance scenarios that are automatically run in the browser, evaluating the behaviour of all layers of a web application (server and client side-scripting). However pyccuracy still have not implemented actions that can be classified as accessible for disabled users like "tabbing navigation", focus possibility for interactive elements, landmarks and header navigation, among other actions. The goal of implementing accessibility actions for pyccuracy is to be able to execute acceptance tests of web applications functionality, considering disabled users task completion with assistive technologies. These users do no rely on the same visual and interactive mechanisms such as mouse and link colors, for example. So pyccuracy actions must consider these characteristics to guarantee that the functionality of the web application is available for all users. From the development perspective, accessibility actions drive automatic accessibility evaluation tools into a Continuous Integration environment. Making it possible to include accessibility non-functional requirements into the development life-cycle of projects and assisting developers while coding solutions for them.

Educational Facilita: another web application that aims to automatically provide users with accessible textual content, through the use of Named Entities Recognition (automatically identifying proper nouns and others entities in the text) and Lexical Elaboration (providing users with simplier versions of the same word) techniques. The application identifies named entities in the text and then it provides the user with additional information about those entities. The additional informations are extracted from Wikipedia. The application also presents synonimous for words that are evaluated as complex or difficult to be understood. Educational Facilita was implemented as a Jetpack extension, and by doing so works as a browser plugin feature.

Scale Tabs: improved version of the 50 lines contest - Scale Tabs Jetpack addon. This addon release used the Addon-SDK (improved version and final release of the Jetpack prototype) and presents improved features (Address bar integration) and improved layout. Its source code is available in github.

YQL-Accessibility: YQL stands for Yahoo! Query Language, as a standard language for querying web resources. It presents a SQL-like syntax that enable queries to be made on RESTful webservices. YQL-Accessibility implements a set of tables (two for the moment) that allow these queries to be executed against web accessibility evaluation websites. It provides developers a simple way and unique way of identifying and reporting accessibility issues that are raised by automatic evaluation tools available in the Web.
